document_data.name: Shaaran
document_data.regions: The [[Shaar]], the [[Lake of Steam (region)|Lake of Steam]]
document_data.mainbody: '''Shaaran''', also called '''Shaartan'''{{Cite dragon/Speaking in Tongues|26}}, was a regional language of [[Southern Faerûn]], and the dominant language of the [[Shaaran]] people.
document_data.Speakers:
Besides the [[Shaar]], other places where Shaaran was commonly spoken among [[human]]s included: [[Amn]], [[Calimshan]], the [[Chondalwood]], [[Chult]], [[Dambrath]], the [[Golden Water]], [[Halruaa]], the [[Lake of Steam (region)|Lake of Steam]], [[Lantan]], [[Lapaliiya]], the [[Nelanther Isles]], [[Sembia]], [[Sespech]], [[Tashalar]], [[Tethyr]], [[Turmish]], [[Unther]], and the [[Vilhon Reach]].{{cite book/Player's Guide to Faerûn|11-16}} It was also sometimes spoken among the [[gold dwarf|gold dwarves]] of the [[Great Rift]],{{cite book/Player's Guide to Faerûn|19}} the [[Wild dwarf|wild dwarves]] of Chult,{{cite book/Player's Guide to Faerûn|22-23}} the wild elves and [[wood elf|wood elves]] of the [[Wealdath]],{{cite book/Player's Guide to Faerûn|26}} and the [[halfling]]s of [[Luiren]].{{cite book/Player's Guide to Faerûn|29-30}}

Scholars divided Shaaran into several dialects, among them, Northern Laker, Southern Laker, True Shaartan, Reacher, Lapaliiyan, and Tharsult.{{Cite dragon/Speaking in Tongues|29}}
document_data.Script: Speakers of the Shaaran tongue used the [[Dethek]] alphabet of the [[dwarves]],{{cite book/FRCS|85}} which they learned from [[Gold dwarf|gold dwarven]] traders from the Great Rift before the rise of the [[Shoon Imperium]].
document_data.History: According to some sources, Shaaran was one of the [[Akalaic languages]], which were all part of the [[Chessan languages]] group. This made Shaaran distantly related to such languages as [[Chessentan language|Chessentan]].
document_data.Examples: Surnames in Shaaran were composed of multiple words. Common examples included Cor Marak, Hiaw Harr, Laumee Harr, Moq Qo Harr, Taw Harr, and Woraw Tarak. Common male names included Awar, Cohis, Damota, Gewar, Hapaw, Laskaw, Moktar, Senesaw, and Tokhis. A female might be named Anet, Bes, Dahvet, Faqem, Idim, Lenet, Moqem, Neghet, or Sihvet.
